Joint Statement by the Enfield Board of Education & Enfield Public Schools

Enfield Public Schools is dedicated to our students. We are heartbroken over the deaths of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, and the countless other black lives unjustifiably lost. We understand that many of our students, especially our black students, are justifiably hurt, confused, scared, and angered about these deaths and the subsequent protests that continue throughout the country. While we cannot meet in school right now, we emphasize that Enfield Public Schools stands with all our students, and we will provide you with opportunities for discussion and counseling. Our goal moving forward will include striving for anti-racism in our schools and community. Our teachers will listen to our black students. We will not dismiss how you feel or tell you to channel your anger in a different way. And to our black students: we stand with you, we listen to you, and we support you. Your life matters.

www.enfieldschools.org

From: EPS Notification System
Subject: Helpful COVID 19 Tips w/ Children

When children and youth watch news on TV about an infectious disease outbreak, read about it in the news, or overhear others discussing it, they can feel scared, confused, or anxious—as much as adults. This is true even if they live far from where the outbreak is taking place and are at little to no actual risk of getting sick. Young people react to anxiety and stress differently than adults. Some may react right away; others may show signs that they are having a difficult time much later. As such, adults do not always know when a child needs help. This tip sheet will help parents, caregivers, and teachers learn some common reactions, respond in a helpful way, and know when to seek support.

As you know, one of the founding tenets of your Enfield Public Schools is giving back to our community. Tomorrow, Friday, December 13th, is “PJ Day for the Kids (of CCMC)”.
ALL of the Enfield Schools are encouraged to wear "SCHOOL and WEATHER ...appropriate PJs" - AND have the option of making a (small) donation to the Center for Cancer & Blood Disorders at CT Children’s Medical Center.

Whether it’s a $1 bill, or loose change, 100% of all donations COLLECTED ON FRIDAY will be sent to CCMC on behalf of your Enfield Public Schools.
We hope you will all consider participating. Remember “We make a difference in Enfield - every child, every day.”

As always, I thank you so much for your time and participation in this worthwhile endeavor.

There are many students and some staff members' children (such as her son Nolan who appears in the video) who greatly appreciate all you are doing for PJ Day tomorrow December 13, 2019.

We have been advised that it is not necessary to dismiss students from school, as the water will not be shut off until 3:00 this afternoon. The school will have normal water flow for restrooms, but we have been asked to not use drinking fountains for the remainder of the day. I want to stress that at no time were any students or staff in any danger, however I wanted to make sure parents were aware of this inconvenience for a few hours.
I want to thank you for your patience in this matter and I will send out additional updates if needed.

Thank you,

Christopher J. Drezek

Tomorrow night, Tuesday, October 15th , 6:00, at Henry Barnard School, KITE will be sponsoring a workshop for parents on Understanding and Redefining Challenging Behavior in Children. Challenging behaviors can be important signals from children expressing needs that they cannot put into words. Peg Oliveria, the Executive Director of the Gesell Institute of Child Development at Yale, will be speaking on what parents need to know to be ready to decipher messages in behaviors, and understand their potential causes in order to decrease outbursts. Join us as we learn to read a child’s behavior as a signal for unmet needs. The child care being offered is currently full, so please make other arrangements.
